reviewText:
This is a long review, so if you just want a summary of why I recommend Dawn of War Gold Edition then skip to the Results section and reading from there.

Relic Entertainment works with Games Workshop to produce an epic real time strategy game that pushed the boundaries of the genre. Dawn of War offers economics, base building, military tactics, and unit management.

Story:
Dawn of War, the first installment on an incredible Warhammer 40,000 saga. The game is based on the planet Tarturus where Ork forces are out of control ravaging the planet and destroying Imperial Guard moral; but, how are they winning so easily? Of course the forces of Chaos are behind the whole war. Dawn of War is the story of Gabrial Angelos and Isador Akios and how they work together to figure out the whole reason behind the presence of Chaos on the imperial garrison at Tarturus.

Campaign:
The campaign offers an epic tale into the 40k lore with amazing twists and turns around every mission. Coupled with the amazing combat system, base management, and resource management this game really packs a punch. The campaign is divided into eleven missions which put you to the test fighting against the Orc Horde and the Chaos Might. As you progress through the campaign you work with the Eldar to defeat a common foe, but as the game dictates the Enemy of your Enemy is not always your friend. The game pits teams together, but at the same time continually draws them apart.

Gameplay:
This game was one of the first to successfully introduce rapid base expansion by requiring players to capture strategic points, which give the player a trickle of endless resources over time. The fast paced gameplay coupled with the macro and micro unit management really made this game a force to be reckoned with. Although the unit population seems rather low (20 personal – 10 vehicle) because the units are based in squads the real unit count is much higher. The battles seem more like full scale wars with you gripping to manage all your units at once. The best feature of this game (and all the Dawn of War games) is that each team is completely different. They have different units, different buildings, upgrades, tactics, resource types, hero units, and strategies. For example the Orc play completely different from the Eldar while both the Eldar and Orcs play completely different from the Space Marines and Chaos Marines. The only two similar teams are the Space Marines and Chaos marines which offer a good learners curve to Dawn of War by giving providing a basic approach to strategy: build barracks, build turrets for defense, use main base to upgrade to new “age” to receive better buildings, build power plants to get power, and upgrade units within armory, etc.

Teams:
There are four teams: Space Marines, Eldar, Orcs, and Chaos Marines. Each team poses different tactics/strategic elements which make you play them differently. The Orcs are based more around unit massing and rapid base expansion. While the Eldar are more about unit specialization and micro base management. The Space Marines and Chaos Marines are essentially the same team set, and fit between tactics of the Orcs and Eldar. Each of the teams units have upgradeable attributes which customize them for specific purposes: weapons, additional squad members, and squad leader units. Each team has special commander units which can be used as heroes buffing the team and supporting military units.

Results:
All and all Dawn of War is a must get game. If you can play older games without constantly yearning for the graphics of the modern day games then you’ll enjoy this game. The gameplay is not outdated, but rather refreshing. As it seems most strategy game developers have diverted from base building, resource management, and mass scale war to simple micromanagement tactic games. I loved this game and all the installments so much I repurchased them all on steam. Despite that I still have all the discs, in functional condition, right next to me.

Pros:
+Economic, Base building, and macro unit management
+Fantastic story and campaign (which is very rare in a strategy game)
+Amazing teams which each play completely differently.
+Fast paced gameplay which requires expansion to acquire resource nodes (but those nodes do not run out like in most games)
+Unit customization allows you to create squads for specific tasks
+Fantastic computer AI that puts you to your wits

Cons:
-Cannot play this game while having another monitor running (if you have two monitors the game will launch but every time you move the mouse to the edge of the screen where your monitor extends the mouse exits the game as if you are playing in Windowed mode).
-Lots of unbalances (don’t worry they fix all of these in the later installments)

reviewText:
10 Years Later, And It Keeps On Giving!

Ive always been a massive fan of the Wh40K Universe, and my love for Games Workshop and all things related, started 10 years ago with this game! I remember my brother pre-ordering  it, and he introduced me into the Universe, and I spent many years watching him play DoW. A few years later, I managed to get my hands on the great title, having been handed down a little beast of a PC ( or had been at the time anyway), and it was my first chance to unleash the power of the Space Marines unto those nasty orks, and the heretic forces of chaos. It was a 3 disk installation, and about a 3 hour wait ; before the game was properly onto the PC. It was well worth it, and the expansions that came out along the years added to the mayhem, it was all part of the experience. I stopped playing DoW as I got rid of my computer, as it was well outdated, and then I suppose it got forgotten in time.

Now back in present day, I became a part of the Steam community, and thought id dig around the room for some games I could add to steam. I found this little gem on my top shelf, so I thought I would give it a go and enter the cd key into steam, I was awfully excited! Put it onto my little laptop, 30 minute installation and I was away, ( so much for those 3 hours installs eh). It all came back to me when I started playing it once again, the music, the classic call of the space marines charging into battle. Me chanting “Burn The Heretic!”, while my Space Marines shoot the hell out of a squad of Chaos marines. Yes, all those requirements of a great RTS game, with hours and hours of enjoyment. You cannot go wrong with good old Dawn Of War, or rather i cannot anyway. The graphics may be quite outdated, and the multiplayer doesn’t hold much of a feature in the game nowadays,  however that certainly does not hinder any enjoyment at all.  Fan of the Wh40k Universe? Used to own the game, but not sure whether to return to serve the emperor? I recommend purchasing this game, and having a whole lot of fun playing it! I personally have a great deal of more of hours to enjoy on this game, reliving the moments of destruction and chaos.

In terms of gameplay elements, Dawn Of War still does not fail to be a very fun, and a practically great game. 10 Years Later And It Sure As Hell Keeps On Giving!
Overall:

+ Everything a classic RTS needs
+ Clever resource system
+ Immersive campaign to sink many hours into
+ Must buy for Warhammer 40k fans
+ Still great at 10 years of age

- Multiplayer servers not great
- Outdated Graphics
- Minor bugs

Solid 9/10

That goes it for my short Dawn of War Steam Review.

Thanks,

The-Sentinel-Gamer

Watching a beloved franchise move between mediums is always difficult. Sometimes it is the awkward transition from movie to videogame. Other times it is the even more awkward transition from videogame to movie. However, every once in a while a franchise weathers the change well, some might argue better off because of the move. The Warhammer 40,000 universe, deftly crafted by the folks at Games Workshop, has attempted the move to videogames before, meeting with varying levels of success. However, it is truly Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War that has made video game players aware of the tabletop brand.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War is a real-time-strategy title that recreates the epic tabletop battles of the Warhammer 40k universe, almost perfectly, on your PC. Epic is truly the best word to describe some of these battles as Space Marines and Imperial Guard do their best to hold off the war hungry Orks, the mysterious Eldar, and destroy the twisted forces of Chaos. Solid start to the franchise however it has a few technical issues initially (lack of widescreen support, sluggish mouse/camera controls compared to its expansions and sequels).

The story is regular grimdark stuff you'd expect from Warhammer 40K. It primarily focuses on the Blood Ravens chapter of the Space Marines so if you want a campaign which allows you to play other factions, then getting Dark Crusade would be a good idea as well (Soulstorm too, though that game also has its issues).

Gameplay-wise this is the solid RTS we've come to know and love over the years. You control squads rather than individual units, some squads are customizable in terms of weapons such as Tactical marines to fit the current situation or need. If you really want to test yourself, play against the insane AI on quick start either by yourself or with friends, you will experience some of the most frantic and gloriously messy RTS battles of its time.

All in all this edition of the original game is solid, though Dark Crusade would be an easier recommendation for those who do not want to deal with some of these technical issues.

reviewText:
A classic real-time strategy game with excellent balance and an interesting campaign story.  Though the graphics may be well past their prime the mechanics of the game are still fun to this day.  I assume Dawn of War was truly a trendsetter in its time though this review in particular is being typed up by someone who first laid their hands on it in 2015.

There are several aspects of this game that really hooked me in.  The fact that your units are -actually- units (small bands of soldiers) was a pleasant surprise.  Each unit can be reinforced, given time and requisition (currency), so it will continue to be an active part of your army as long as you replace your losses.  This prevents replacements from clogging up your new unit construction at your base and allows you to keep pressing your advantage without worrying about logistics as soldiers arrive on your frontlines instead of far behind them.  Additionally, I enjoyed being able to personally customize my own units.  If I wanted one unit of Space Marines to excel at eliminating other heavy infantry I could deck them out with a few plasma rifles while if I was going for more an anti-vehicle/building approach with that unit I could supply them with rocket launchers instead.

Though I personally can't think of any complaints on the game as a whole other than stretching and pointing at the outdated graphics, I can say that I enjoyed the campaign far more than I did the random scenarios or multiplayer.  I found that I had a blast playing the game with objectives and a story but the Starcraft model of 'create a horde as fast as possbile and zerg the other base' got old quickly.  However, I am aware that there are -plenty- of players out there who would find that a great addition to the level of fun that they experience, not a detriment.

I recommend this game to all RTS fans especially those who enjoy the more old-school variants.  I picked it up in a sale and got almost fifteen hours out of the Game of the Year version by itself; fifteen hours that I still believe were very well spent.

reviewText:
Dawn of War is a timeless classic. I've played this game years ago but it seems it hasn't lost any of it's sweetness.

Here are some things that make Dawn of War different:

Gameplay:1. Resource management is basically reduced to territory control.
The more strategic points you control and the better you fortify them, the more of the 'requisition' resource you get.

Investing into strategic point fortification, makes them harder to capture and after simple upgrade, they can shoot at your enemies. So you're basically building sentry turrets that mine resources for you.

2. Squad reinforcment
Most units operate as squads. You get a squad of 4 marines, and you can add to it (reinforce) untill you got 8 marines. With upgrades you can add a sergeant who has a skill to rally them and instantly restore Morale. If few of your marines die, you can just reinforce the squad, and they will appear at the squad position at the fraction of a cost of a new squad. This allows you to push forward after a battle with little delay without moving new forces from base to the frontlines.

3. Squad equipment
You can equip your squads with weapons effective against certain types of units, you can mix them up in one squad, or just have a dedicated squad for every type. This provides interesting choices and allows for more variety in your tactics.

4. Cover
Having your units sit in a bomb crater, behind a wall or in the trees, makes them harder to hit and they also feel better (see Morale)

5. Morale
Certain situations make units lose their composure and lower their effectiveness. Especially when they fight outnumbered, or against intimidating opponents or weapons (flamethrowers, snipers).

6. Space considerations with 'macro'
You need to think about the space your forces are going to operate in. You wont fit 3 tanks and 4 squads of infantry into a narrow street, without totally compromising their ability to efficiently move and operate. They will get stuck, bump into each other and wont be able to all get to the front to shoot the enemy you encounter. Some people say it's a downside and speak about bugged pathing". Pathing is ok

One of my favourite strategy games, and I am not a big strategy player at all. This game was the dawn of the Dawn of War series, and an outstanding game in its own right.

In the single player campaign, you play as the Space Marines. Through various maps and settings, the story builds towards a handful of epic confrontations, and the difficulty progresses in like manner. Playing on normal is a little too easy, but push the difficulty up and you will find yourself challenged (disclaimer: I'm not very good at RTS games).

Venture into multiplayer, and you will have four races at your disposal, each with their pros and cons: Chaos Marines, Elder, Orks and Space Marines. I found the multiplayer portion of the game to be well-balanced, with end game units strong but not so readily accessible to make one race overpowered.

Lastly, if you're playing on any system built in the last seven-eight years, I HIGHLY recommend following the below guide to get widescreen resolutions working (all credit goes to OP):

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=205040803

reviewText:
There are two ways in which a real time strategy game can easily screw up.

The first is to have far too much micro-management.
The second is to feel limited in scale, ability or grandure.

Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War expertly sidesteps both issues and delivers a fun, engaging campaign to save a planet from Ork invasion.
Of course more is going on, and you will soon meet all of the other factions as well.

What works so well in this game compared to most other strategy games is the fact that infantry units are comprised of squads of up to 10 individual soldiers. These can be tuned with new gear and restocked when they fall.
It allows for an easy way to still have an impressive army steam-roll an enemy encampment without having to micro-manage everything.

I had fun, and will definitely pick up the sequel (EDIT: Then I did, it's great too. Review here)
Avoid this game if you can't stomach the dead-pan Space Marine seriousness though, it can get a bit much (and it's the only faction that has a campaign).

Dawn of War is one of the greatest single-player RPG's I have ever played. reviewText: By creating WH40K:DoW, Relic Entertainment has brought into existence the best Warhammer video game adaption up to date. Dawn of War is a title which doesn't just simply entertain, it takes a special place in the player's memory, and it does so due to two reasons. The first and the more considerable of these two reasons lies in the very fact that this game is set in the grim future of the 41st millennium, a future where there is only war, death and the laughter of thirsting gods. However, in order to adapt such a brilliant setting to the screen of computers, experienced, devoted and skilled game designers had to take matters into their own hands. This is where the second reason for the titles success comes into play - the developers. Relic Entertainment had the right framework to build their RTS upon from the very beginning, but even with such a great basis as the WH40k universe, talent and thoroughness were required so as to make a good quality game. Before DoW, several WH40k titles were already developed for the PC, with most of them being released in the 90's. While these predecessors were usually of good quality, certain factors prevented them from being as accomplished as DoW, graphical limitations being one of them. Relic Entertainment utilized the technology which was available in 2004 to implement the best possible graphics into their RTS, and graphics are indeed one of the most remarkable attributes which Dawn of War possesses, even to this day. The gameplay mechanics are also unique and exceptional, as are all the other aspects of the game.\n\nIn Dawn of War, Relic Entertainment employed a semi-innovative resource control system. Unlike in some older, well known real-time strategies where the player had to directly gather resources which fueled his armies growth, in DoW the economy revolves around control over strategic points that are scattered all across the battlefield. The amount of the strategic points controlled is crucial since they directly affect the players requisition income, thus forcing the opposing combatants to constantly fight for the control over territory. In addition to strategic points which play the primary resource role and grant requisition, DoW also has a secondary resource called power. This resource is just as essential as requisition, since power is required for researching or upgrading technologies and abilities, and is also spent when deploying advanced units and vehicles. In order to gain power resource points, the commander must build power generator structures either near his base of operations or at special slag deposits which grant more power income. By the time Dawn of War was released, the requisition control system was new but not unheard of, since there were already games that utilized a somewhat similar concept. Massive Entertainment's Ground Control II for an example, which was released approximately three months before DoW, used a system called acquisition in which points were earned through the capturing of victory locations. Later on, Massive Entertainment used the same system in their well acclaimed RTT World in Conflict. In fairness it must be said, that even though Relic's resource control system was at that time both original and well designed, it wasn't actually their invention. They did, however, put this system to good use, because in terms of economical balance, DoW is a perfectly designed RTS. Missions in-game usually alternate between jungles and ravaged urban ruins, with Fog of War being persistent in those areas of the map which either have not yet been uncovered or were abandoned by allied forces. In battle, the environment plays a minor strategic role as well, on account of that in Dawn of War, certain types of terrain can provide troops with either good cover, granting them a protection bonus, or harmful cover which exposes the troops and makes them vulnerable to enemy fire. In general, terrain and the surrounding environment both contribute to the tactical detail of the game, with infantry traversing faster over certain terrain types, while treaded vehicles will move slower. Infantry squads all have morale that affects their combat effectiveness. An infantry squad with broken morale will be much less effective in combat, and will need to retreat in order to replenish their fighting spirit. Squad leaders also give each squad a significant morale boost. Enemy infantry has morale as well, and certain weapons, such as for an example a flamethrower, can break it faster, rendering enemy formations broken and in a state of moral dismay. In Dawn of War, there are four different factions which are anything but similar and are all driven to annihilate each other. All four of these factions have their own distinctive units, structures and strategies. Units can be divided into infantry and vehicles, with infantry groups usually being versatile and possessing the ability to capture strategic points, while vehicles often take an assault force role. Dawn of War provides the player with an immense arsenal of weaponry, including artillery, tanks and walker vehicles. Unlike some RTS games where opposing armies often have visually different but functionally identical units, in DoW units which are exclusive to one certain faction are unique in the sense that they rarely have a counterpart amongst the three other factions. Therefore, all units in DoW are not only distinguishable by their appearance, but also by their abilities and properties. The Tech-Tree in the game is well developed, each faction has numerous types of infantry, vehicles, skills, technologies and upgrades. The player can also upgrade his primary and defensive structures to go higher in the tech tree, further benefiting his fighting force. In the single-player campaign, the player will have the opportunity to play as the Space Marines Blood Ravens chapter, taking the role of Force Commander Gabriel Angelos. Throughout 11 bloody missions, players will first fight against the Ork menace, will struggle against the mysterious Eldar, and will then finally engage against the traitorous Chaos Space Marines. Most of the missions are focused on elimination of the enemy base and army. Dawn of War offers three levels of difficulty, with the Insane" difficulty level being the most entertaining and challenging one. The gameplay in Dawn of War can be described as balanced

Just like the other 885,363 PC gamers out there, a few weeks ago I picked up a copy of the Humble THQ Bundle. Not only was it a great deal for some games, it was also a way to help a company in need.  Now everyone can argue the ‘Hows’ and ‘Whys’ of THQ’s current situation, but at the end of the day gamers aren’t overly interested in their products.  And its hurting them more than it has in years.  But this isn’t an financial overview of the current fiscal situation of THQ.

This is a Bargain Bin Breakdown, and the game is Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War.  And you may have figured out prior to the break that I’ve never played anything Warhammer 40,000 before.  So its another unbiased review that falls completely on the games merit!  I love it when that happens.  However, with schedules tightening and life being life, I’m not always able to play an entire game.  Its actually a difficult choice on what to play when and for how long.  And having nine new games added to my Steam games list only makes it more of a challenge.  Do you realize I’ve had L.A. Noire for months and have yet to play it?!

But I’m rambling again…

My plan with Dawn of War was to play at least 3 missions of the main campaign then a skirmish as the enemy faction.  This, in theory, would give me enough to rate the games mechanics, story, and balance.  After which point I could continue to play, if the game had captured my interest, or begin writing my review.  Everything started well.  I played the tutorial so I could see which type of RTS this was.  Then I started the first mission.

I was impressed at how well they tell the story with the opening sequences.  Even if I wasn’t really following what was going on with the story, the way in which it was given was very well done.  Unfortunately, to me its just another Orc vs Human story that I can’t find interest in.

And unfortunately I've never had any interest into the types of worlds where Orcs are present.  I am a fan of Science Fiction, but Fantasy hasn't ever done it for me.  Orcs, Elves, Humans, Middle Earth, whatever or where ever it is, hasn't been my thing.  I've played the WarCraft games, I’ve seen the Lord of the Rings movies, I attempted to read a few different stories in the past.  But none of it really sparks much interest in me.  So the real challenge with games of this genre is to excite me in other ways.  Which has happened, but is a rare occurrence.

I can’t find any of the Orcs terrifying, or anything other than plain stupid, and in this game its no different, they just look goofy.  Sure the graphics are dated, but not so bad, and I kinda enjoyed them since they reminded me of Star Wars Galaxies.  But the models themselves, and the designs that were chosen.  A part of my lack of interest in the fantasy worlds fall under technology.  The worlds always look very similar to the Middle Ages, but then there will be some sort of advanced technology that just doesn't fit.

The Humans are actually fine in this regard since everything of theirs looks and matches the advance space faring race type.  However the Ocrs look like a lesser advanced race, until they bust out the battle units.  And I just can’t accept being so far advanced on one side and looking a few centuries behind on the other.

But story and setting or not I can still play a game.  So I brushed aside my opinions of the story and played on, enjoying the games itself.  And the mechanics are amazing.  The first mission did a great job of holding my hand and guiding me through the process of playing.  Sure, I had learned a bit from the tutorial, but had quit that about halfway in.  It didn’t take long to finish the mission, and even take a moment to realize that I have genuinely enjoyed playing the game.

Then came the second mission.  And while I did enjoy myself for most of it, my enjoyment started to ween.  There came a point in the mission where my troops, just a couple of infantry squads, felt so overpowered.  There wasn’t anything they could’t take out in a matter of seconds.  I expected it to be on the easier side this early in the game, but this was ridiculous.  The hand holding was still there, which wasn’t a big deal, just not really necessary.

In between he missions are more story pieces.  And I’m not sure what to call them, since they’re not FMV or cinematic’s   They are scripted sequences that take place on the map itself.  Often before you take over control of the game and start the mission.  It was really well done, and probably my favorite thing out of this game.

I did also love the dead units not disappearing from the battlefield.  There’s just something about watching your enemies slain pile up.  It really brings to light just how many souls you’ve taken in your quest for vengeance.

Onto the third mission, this is where everything changed.  This is where the game got real.

It starts with a pre-built base and units guarding checkpoints.  It starts with you coming under attack.  And the attacks don’t waver.  Now I will offer the chance that I was completely missing some important factoid that makes the mission easier.  But I did try it three separate times.  Each time I was unable to build up or maintain a defense force while also building an attack force.  And after awhile the tanks rolled in, and I hadn’t a chance.

That’s when a friend informed me of a Mech unit that was located on the map.  So on the fourth attempt I managed to hold my ground long enough to seek out this unit.  I found it and unlocked the ability to build more of them.  And with these new units I swept through the lands slaughtering all that came in my path.  And completed the mission.

But here is the problem.  While on previous missions my infantry units mowed through people and buildings like they were all made of paper, now the enemy has tanks and is mowing through me in the same fashion.  Until I get these Mech units, and it sways back into my favor.  I don’t like this.  This doesn’t feel like balance.  It feels like the scales are swaying back and forth.  One side always has an advantage over the other, its just the who that changes.

So I tried a Skirmish, just to see.  A standard 8 team Free For All, where I played as the same faction that I was in the campaign.  It was pretty uneventful, I may have had it on too easy of a difficulty.  But I managed to build a base and maintain my defenses from a few attacks, and then build up my attack force.  Then I sent them out to battle, and they walked right through the enemy like paper…

Now, when I play a mission I tend to have double the needed units to succeed, sometimes triple.  I love nothing more than having units in the triple digits.  Dawn of War, like most others of its RTS type, has a population limit.  Sometimes I can work with this, but I always feel like its not enough.

But don’t think I’m going to trash this game because of the apparent major change in the difficulty curve from mission two to mission three.  Or because the balance feels to be in constant shift.  Because of what I did play of this game I did enjoy.  A lot of this game I thought was great and pretty ground breaking for its time.  I just can’t create any connection with the characters, units, or setting.

But I have no plans to uninstalling or forgetting about Dawn of War, I will keep it there, ready for when I’m ready to come back to it.  But most of all this time spent has shown me where Company of Heroes really came from.  Which seeing as I’ve been obsessed with that game is a great way to open my eyes to its evolution.  Things that I don’t like, or don’t feel like they work in Dawn of War are not present in Company of Heroes.  While other things are expanded on and evolved into better thing

Just like the other 885,363 PC gamers out there, a few weeks ago I picked up a copy of the Humble THQ Bundle. Not only was it a great deal for some games, it was also a way to help a company in need.  Now everyone can argue the ‘Hows’ and ‘Whys’ of THQ’s current situation, but at the end of the day gamers aren’t overly interested in their products.  And its hurting them more than it has in years.  But this isn’t an financial overview of the current fiscal situation of THQ.

This is a Bargain Bin Breakdown, and the game is Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War.  And you may have figured out prior to the break that I’ve never played anything Warhammer 40,000 before.  So its another unbiased review that falls completely on the games merit!  I love it when that happens.  However, with schedules tightening and life being life, I’m not always able to play an entire game.  Its actually a difficult choice on what to play when and for how long.  And having nine new games added to my Steam games list only makes it more of a challenge.  Do you realize I’ve had L.A. Noire for months and have yet to play it?!

But I’m rambling again…

My plan with Dawn of War was to play at least 3 missions of the main campaign then a skirmish as the enemy faction.  This, in theory, would give me enough to rate the games mechanics, story, and balance.  After which point I could continue to play, if the game had captured my interest, or begin writing my review.  Everything started well.  I played the tutorial so I could see which type of RTS this was.  Then I started the first mission.

I was impressed at how well they tell the story with the opening sequences.  Even if I wasn’t really following what was going on with the story, the way in which it was given was very well done.  Unfortunately, to me its just another Orc vs Human story that I can’t find interest in.

And unfortunately I've never had any interest into the types of worlds where Orcs are present.  I am a fan of Science Fiction, but Fantasy hasn't ever done it for me.  Orcs, Elves, Humans, Middle Earth, whatever or where ever it is, hasn't been my thing.  I've played the WarCraft games, I’ve seen the Lord of the Rings movies, I attempted to read a few different stories in the past.  But none of it really sparks much interest in me.  So the real challenge with games of this genre is to excite me in other ways.  Which has happened, but is a rare occurrence.

I can’t find any of the Orcs terrifying, or anything other than plain stupid, and in this game its no different, they just look goofy.  Sure the graphics are dated, but not so bad, and I kinda enjoyed them since they reminded me of Star Wars Galaxies.  But the models themselves, and the designs that were chosen.  A part of my lack of interest in the fantasy worlds fall under technology.  The worlds always look very similar to the Middle Ages, but then there will be some sort of advanced technology that just doesn't fit.

The Humans are actually fine in this regard since everything of theirs looks and matches the advance space faring race type.  However the Ocrs look like a lesser advanced race, until they bust out the battle units.  And I just can’t accept being so far advanced on one side and looking a few centuries behind on the other.

But story and setting or not I can still play a game.  So I brushed aside my opinions of the story and played on, enjoying the games itself.  And the mechanics are amazing.  The first mission did a great job of holding my hand and guiding me through the process of playing.  Sure, I had learned a bit from the tutorial, but had quit that about halfway in.  It didn’t take long to finish the mission, and even take a moment to realize that I have genuinely enjoyed playing the game.

Then came the second mission.  And while I did enjoy myself for most of it, my enjoyment started to ween.  There came a point in the mission where my troops, just a couple of infantry squads, felt so overpowered.  There wasn’t anything they could’t take out in a matter of seconds.  I expected it to be on the easier side this early in the game, but this was ridiculous.  The hand holding was still there, which wasn’t a big deal, just not really necessary.

In between he missions are more story pieces.  And I’m not sure what to call them, since they’re not FMV or cinematic’s   They are scripted sequences that take place on the map itself.  Often before you take over control of the game and start the mission.  It was really well done, and probably my favorite thing out of this game.

I did also love the dead units not disappearing from the battlefield.  There’s just something about watching your enemies slain pile up.  It really brings to light just how many souls you’ve taken in your quest for vengeance.

Onto the third mission, this is where everything changed.  This is where the game got real.

It starts with a pre-built base and units guarding checkpoints.  It starts with you coming under attack.  And the attacks don’t waver.  Now I will offer the chance that I was completely missing some important factoid that makes the mission easier.  But I did try it three separate times.  Each time I was unable to build up or maintain a defense force while also building an attack force.  And after awhile the tanks rolled in, and I hadn’t a chance.

That’s when a friend informed me of a Mech unit that was located on the map.  So on the fourth attempt I managed to hold my ground long enough to seek out this unit.  I found it and unlocked the ability to build more of them.  And with these new units I swept through the lands slaughtering all that came in my path.  And completed the mission.

But here is the problem.  While on previous missions my infantry units mowed through people and buildings like they were all made of paper, now the enemy has tanks and is mowing through me in the same fashion.  Until I get these Mech units, and it sways back into my favor.  I don’t like this.  This doesn’t feel like balance.  It feels like the scales are swaying back and forth.  One side always has an advantage over the other, its just the who that changes.

So I tried a Skirmish, just to see.  A standard 8 team Free For All, where I played as the same faction that I was in the campaign.  It was pretty uneventful, I may have had it on too easy of a difficulty.  But I managed to build a base and maintain my defenses from a few attacks, and then build up my attack force.  Then I sent them out to battle, and they walked right through the enemy like paper…

Now, when I play a mission I tend to have double the needed units to succeed, sometimes triple.  I love nothing more than having units in the triple digits.  Dawn of War, like most others of its RTS type, has a population limit.  Sometimes I can work with this, but I always feel like its not enough.

But don’t think I’m going to trash this game because of the apparent major change in the difficulty curve from mission two to mission three.  Or because the balance feels to be in constant shift.  Because of what I did play of this game I did enjoy.  A lot of this game I thought was great and pretty ground breaking for its time.  I just can’t create any connection with the characters, units, or setting.

But I have no plans to uninstalling or forgetting about Dawn of War, I will keep it there, ready for when I’m ready to come back to it.  But most of all this time spent has shown me where Company of Heroes really came from.  Which seeing as I’ve been obsessed with that game is a great way to open my eyes to its evolution.  Things that I don’t like, or don’t feel like they work in Dawn of War are not present in Company of Heroes.  While other things are expanded on and evolved into better thing

This game is one of the finest RTS games ever to grace the genre. The game truly holds well even to this day, well over a decade afters its initial release. The game offers an interested and very fun singleplayer campaign where you play as the  Blood Ravens Space Marine chapter as they fight against a massive Ork force on an imperial planet. It's up to you to use your brain and tactical sense to destroy the Ork menace. But as time goes on the forces of Chaos arrive as well as the elusive Eldar and the stakes only begin to rise. The gameplay is solid. From the army commands as well as base building and management. Unlike other, older, RTS games the way you gain recources is by capturing and holding points that are around the battlemap making those areas complete hotspots for some epic large battles. You get to command large armies and pit them against other large armies, unique units and buildings per factions (four factions are available in the game), an army painter (very basic, but still fun to use custom armies in skirmish), and overall the game has a lot to offer. There are some downsides sadly, but these are more in the technical side rather than the game itself, the game does not support 16:9 resolutions, but with some mods you are able to force a 16:9 resolution in the game, but the mini map tends to bug out. The unit path finding can be a bit wonky at times as well and artillery units can be a real pain if you don't know how to properly use them, but overall nothing too serious, just minor inconveniences. This is a great game for both RTS fans and Warhammer 40k fans or if you're a fan of both, you're doing yourself an unjustice by not owning and playing this great game.

There are a lot of RTS games out there and Dawn of War is one of the best of the best. It actually does feel like you're playing the Warhammer 40K tabletop game, except without all of the hassle. While the graphics are lacking nowadays, the gameplay and fun factor are still top-notch. There is base building, but it doesn't require an insane amount of micro-managing like SC2 does, for example. What makes this game so enjoyable to me is that you spend the majority of your time managing your massive army and it's just straight up fun to do.

The campaign is OK and worth a single playthrough. Just be prepared for drawn out conversations, overly wordy narration, and some incredibly terrible voice acting (though it does have a particular charm). The meat and potatoes is the multiplayer mode, which you can play against CPU bots or online. In this version of the game you can pick between four factions which include Space Marines, Orks, Eldar and Chaos.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Dawn of War is one of my favorite RTS games, even though I suck ♥♥♥ at them, Dawn of War is one I find myself picking up again and again to play. The game takes the setting in the Warhammer 40k universe and lets you control one of a few factions from the Warhammer lore to battle other players. The factions in this game are the Space Marines, Eldar, Orks, and Chaos Space Marines.

The game, and the series, has many pros; the game has base building, units in squads, vehicles, and pretty decent destruction effects. The aingle player is decent I think and is a good few hours of gameplay and then the multiplayer is like a lot of RTS games however it has resource points you take and hold on the map to keep a steady flow of resources to your side to build buildings and troops. The game offers a variety of modes players can wage battle in such as take and hold (which is taking critical points and holding them to win), annihalation (which is just killing the other side), and capture the flag and so on.

The only bad thing I think when it comes to this game is that it is an older game and a few computers have had issues running it but for the most part it seems to be able to run on the newer systems. If not then most fixes can be found online.

In the end if you enjoy games like Company of Heroes, Starcraft, Warcraft, etc. then I would recommend this game. The gameplay is well done, pretty well balanced, and enjoyable to play with some friends or just to pass some times with. If you are a fan of the Warhammer 40k lore and setting than this game is great.

reviewText:
So this is my first entry into the Warhammer 40,000 universe and I must say I was very impressed. Simple to understand, excessively violent and nearly a perfect strategy game that marks the pinnacle of RTS games of it's era.

The story, not to spoil a single thing is superb for an RTS. In my opinion, the story is easily better than that of many games today. With it's twists, turns and full stops, it's a rather moving ride. As you complete missions, the story unfolds a little more until it all breaks down and becomes less of a story to do with missions than all out annihilation. Spending 15 hours with the Blood Raven Space Marine chapter tearing apart Ork by Ork, Eldar by Eldar and Chaos by ♥♥♥♥ing Chaos was a blast and even towards the end never lacked for excitement. However that leads me to slight dismay with the game. Even early in the 15 hours I got sick of playing the same units and the same strategy, the campaign never challanged me to try something different. Maybe it was because I was playing on Normal rather than anything hardcore, but it felt that way. The only time it made me do something strikingly different was when I was pushing away at early linear tutorial missions. However despite this, it's still an excellent game - especially for it's time. Relic, the guys who developed this, along with other award-winning and highly recommended RTS games such as Homeworld and the Company of Heroes franchise did an great job polishing it, making it look strikingly beautiful (of course for it's time) and simple but not bland.

Now onto the Skirmish/Multiplayer. Basically the same mode where on varied maps players/AI must battle it out to complete different objectives based on game modes and on many different maps. Map variety is great, even without the expansions and despite not doing much in the skirmish, you could tell that you'd be in for something different just looking at the startup skirmish screen. Whether you play as the Eldar, Orks, Space Marines or Chaos (plus more if you have expansions and use the CD keys on those expansions) you have a varied playstyle and each race is balanced making skirmishes fair each time. However, another point I must bring up, and I've noticed in Relic's other game - Company of Heroes is, that the AI seems to just do the same each game. I may have said the maps make varied gameplay, but mainly against players or if the bots are decently hard. The AI 9/10 do the same thing each time and makes them very predictable leaving them easily destroyable.

If you skipped reading that, you're ♥♥♥♥ing lazy, but I came prepared:

Pros

- Varied Skirmish Maps
- Balanced and different factions to play as on skirmish.
- Great story was it's twists and turns.

Cons

- AI often predictable on skirmishes.
- Campaign, despite fun, becomes rather repetitive towards the end. One term: Annihilation.

Overall I'd rate it easily a 8.5/10.

reviewText:
(Reviews of mine posted on the expansions are the exact same as this one)

Enjoy playing a game that stands tall and proud even now. Enjoy playing a game that has virtually no balance problems. Enjoy playing a game with 9 different races that somehow all play the same, something that Starcraft 2 Heart of The Swarm currently is beginning to fail at.

Enjoy playing a game where each race has a super weapon that is literally a giant unit from a giant tank, to a large, fat pyramid-ish cube with a giant laser beam, or even a big pig...thing with lasers on it's head, bigger than the swimming pool you went to last month.

Trust me... these Super Weapons put Command and Conquer's Super Weapons at the kiddie table, they make them look like pea shooters almost. Oh... what's that? One is an energy field that makes all tanks and vehicles invulnerable for a short time? One of them is an ion blast fired from a sattelite in space or something? One of them is a nuke?

Only the Nuke super weapon stands up to any of these.

The game works off of unlimited resources known as Requisition and Power. Power, you make generators to make, and Requisition is gained from taking and holding points throughout a map. Both can be upgraded in a different way to produce more resources faster.

Anyonewho is a fan of strategy games who has NOT played this one is just simply missing out.

This game is the closest anyone will ever get to a seemingly perfect game in it's own rights, and to add to it, it's got wonderful voiceacting, awesome soundtracks and rather impressive visuals for it's time, all of which stands just aswell today.

Hardcore RTS fans can agree that if you are a HUGE fan of the Real-Time Strategy Game, you owe it to yourself to try this.

The game has 3 expansions, the first one adds The Imperial Gaurd, the second adds the Tau and Necrons, and the thirds adds the Sisters of Battle and the Dark Eldar.

All 3 add onto the game and simply make it one of the best if not the best RTS in existence so far.

Also only Soulstorm has much of an actual multiplayer, because people only play it, so if multiplayer is what you're looking for... well try out the skirmish mode, and if you like this, get the 3 expansions and join us in the crusade to kill eachother!

This game is easily an 8/10, it's simply gaming bliss.

reviewText:
A great introduction to the Warhammer 40k universe. If you're like me you stumbled upon this by friends that either played the tabletop game, were into the lore or played this. As an RTS it is quite an entertaining one to play as you have your campagin of course which is really good as you play as a Space Marine chapter known as the Blood Ravens. It's even got a decent story to go with it since it takes place on a slowly chaotic planet filled with Orks, Eldar and Chaos Space Marines. I sort of wished the campaign was a little more varied in how you only play as Space Marines but it's still a rather competent campaign at that.

The game has lots of units to play as and often the game is territorial based meaning that you you have to keep moving and taking over relics and strategic points to get the resources you need to win the battle. It's a pretty good incentive instead of the usual building a huge army and steamrolling everything (not that steamrolling is fun but) it's refreshing to see a change in the RTS formula. When you're done with your campaign you have your skirmish modes where you play  against the AI with four factions to choose from (Space Marines, Chaos Space Marines, Eldar and Orks) and online mode where you play with friends and randoms which is quite nice and fun to play. Lastly you have your army painter which let's you customize your faction's armor and logo colour. It's cool but a little limited though not a lot of RTS games lets you do that.

Good campaign, fun skirmishes and online play makes Dawn of War a worthy RTS to have in your collection. It's over 10 years old and as a recent newbie to the series it is still rather fun to pick up and play. I give it an 8/10.

reviewText:
At this point, I could honestly only suggest this game to hardcore RTS fans, specifically those who are into WarCraft 3 but could expand into some new lore and mechanics. It's just aged a great deal. It looks and feels bad. The soundtrack seems on par with the sequels though, and there seems to be plenty of story in the campaign, and a neat territorial conquest theme to the campaign that the DoW2 series did not have.

Now, I'm typically not a fan of true RTS games, which might be why I feel like Dawn of War 2 was a vastly superior set of games in ALL ways, but I can understand that the first Dawn of War series of content here can hold some people's attention. They're definitely more focused on more multitasking and bigger squadrons. That kind of stuff honestly just hurts my brain. I much prefer DoW2's 4-Hero Unit campaign structure, and it's Last Stand mode (though now largely unplayed).

As far as multiplayer goes, I cannot comment, as I know my role there. I am no use to any team. That's probably where this first series shines, from what I hear.

I know shouldn't let the Campaign overly influence my opinion on this game, but man I found this boring. It hasn't aged very well at all. I can forgive the poor draw distance, and the chunky graphics, as technology moves on long after games have been made.

Yet... the story was pretty boring and by the book, which is a shame when you consider the huge amount of lore you can draw from the Warhammer Universe. Like other RTS before and after it, Dawn of War suffers from the ease in which you can build up a super army and just blitz your way through the map.

There are some nice animations and kill sequences within the game, which is a nice little touch.

I'll give this game another go somewhere down the line and play Skirmmish/Multiplayer against other people, which I think will be a fairer reflection on what it has to offer.
I do like the idea of the Army Painter tool to create unique paint designs.

Warhammer 40k: Dawn of War was RTS game from the universe developed by Relic.

Gameplay is large scale and epic with a mix between base building and managing units. There are two main resources: Power and requisition. Requisition is used to make buildings, units, upgrades. The same can also be said of power, which generates slower. To acquire these resources you need to capture points on the map and hold them. You can field a variety of units including infantry, land vehicles, heroes and super heavy unit. All units cost requisition to make. Upgrades are also available for purchase from buildings. You can upgrade squad with weapons or more members.

There are two modes to play with: Campaign and skirmish. Campaign follows Captain Gabriel Angelos of the Blood Ravens chapter of space marines as he faces off against the orc horde. Unlike the latter entries to the series, the campaign is set into levels.  Each level of the campaign starts you off with a few units. Your goal is to build a base and then an army to accomplish various objectives. Such objectives are split between primary and secondary ones and involve either destroying a specific building or enemy unit. Completing all primary objectives will win the level, while secondary ones are optional. Skirmish mode has you face off against up to 7 players/bots in game modes such as annihilation and victory point capture. There are a total of 4 races available to play as including Eldar, Space marines, Orcs and Chaos. The other expansion packs (ie Dark Crusade, Winter Assault, Soulstorm) will allow you to select more races to play as and against, should you acquire them.

Audio is excellent. The weapon sound effects feel as they should. Background music fits well with combat. Voice acting for campaign (as units) are well done.

If you are looking for a good RTS game with lots of action or you are interested in the 40K universe, this is where to start.

To start: I used to add a much longer header to these reviews, but since it often made the reviews too long to submit, I've opted to leave it on my Backloggery.

Gameplay: One thing that's very difficult not to do when talking about any base-building RTS, let alone a military Sci-Fi RTS, is to not compare it to Starcraft, especially considering the influence that the Warhammer 40k world present in Starcraft. After all, there's a race of humans kinda like the Terrans, there's an alien race like the Protoss, and while not present in this game, there is a race similar to the Zerg. Also much like Starcraft, the gameplay is centered around building bases.

The differences come in, as you might expect, with the gameplay. While this is something of a personal taste, I really do quite like how resources are handled in this game. Your two basic resources are Requisition (kinda like Minerals) and Power (kinda like Vespene). You gain requisition from controlling Strategic Points on the map. It is also from these Strategic Points that you build your base, from which you can build in a radius that expands up to a certain point. Unlike Starcraft, you gain resources at a set rate per minute, which is slow enough to require you to think about what you wanna build, as opposed to spamming harvesters all day. Power is gained from building generators, and much like Requisition, is gained at a set rate per minute. There are also Slag Deposits on some maps, which you can capture and build a special generator on, allowing a bit more strategy with your expansion.

Units are produced in squads, and vehicles have their own unit cap outside of the squad unit cap. With some research, you can increase your squad cap to 20, and your vehicle cap to 10. While this doesn't sound like much, keep in mind that each squad can have up to ten people in it, reaching Starcraft's famous 200 unit limit very easily, and surpassing it with vehicle count. I do wish that your construction units didn't count as one squad, which can be especially obnoxious as there is no way of recalling your construction units other than sending them out to maybe punch the enemy's base or something.

While the game doesn't necessarily have as many units as Starcraft, the matter of unit composition is largely handled by equipment. Your basic squad can be outfitted with four different special weapons, of which each squad can have up to four specially equipped members. Another aspect to this game is its Morale system, in which you can use particularly gruesome attacks to break apart squads, leaving them easy for the pickings as well as discouraging some easy rushes from time to time.

The single player campaign is somewhat disappointing, as it only features the Space Marines. I'll talk more about the story later, but for now know that there aren't Eldar, Ork or Chaos Marine campaigns (Eldar being the kinda-Protoss race and Necron being the unlisted kinda-Zerg race). There are apparently campaigns in the expansions, but since I haven't played them yet, I can't speak for them.

Now, we come to the important question: how fun is the game? This was my first legit" introduction to the Real-Time Strategy genre

One of my favourite strategy games of all-time, Dawn of War is a real-time strategy game set in the futuristic Warhammer 40000 universe.
Like most strategy games, you have a base building. You build more buildings which give you access to units and abilities. You can then uprgrade units and building to improve your army. To build buildings or units you need resources which can be acquired by capturing points and buildng power stations. Buildings, units, abilities and playstyles change according to the race that you choose. In the original Dawn of War, you have access to 4 races: Space Marines, Chaos, Orcs and Eldar.
In the single player campaign mode, you play as the Space Marines in a story driven campaign. The storyline is interesting enough to keep you engaged and maps are varied enough to stay interesting for whatever difficulty level you have selected.
There are also single player scenarios, where you pick and any army and map and then play. Also there is online multiplayer to play with human opponents. Maps can hold between 2 and 8 players who can be divided into teams if desired.
There is also a customiser where you can choose a race and customise the look of your units and buildings to create a unique looking army for yourself.
There are also 3 expansions which further build on this: Winter Assault, Dark Crusade and Soulstorm.

Winter Assault features new maps, storyline and the addition of the Imperial Guard race. The storyline features the option to play through it as Good (Imperial Guard and Eldar) or Evil (Chaos and Orks) with an ending that changes depending on who you pick to play the final mission with.

Dark Crusade again features completely new maps, storyline, addition of the Tau race and the Necron race as well as new units for existing races. The single player game is changed slightly as you now have an overworld view of the planet that all these races are fighting on. You choose which areas you wish to battle in first. The more areas you acquire, the more resources that are open to you. You can also acquire honor guard units (rare powerful hero units) as well as equipment to give to your race's leader, which enhances their stats and abilities. This gives the game a pseudo-RPG element. You eliminate other races by invading their home region and taking it, but they can do the same to do.
Again, the storyline is engaging enough, but not as immersive or as intense as in the previous games.

Soulstorm once again builds further on what has come before by featuring more completely new maps, storyline, addition of the Sisters of Battle race and the Dark Eldar race, as well as even more units for existing races. The single layer features an overworld view of several planets and maintains the pseudo-RPG elements of Dark Crusade.

Overall, this is a great strategy series to get is you are a fan of the genre or of Warhammer 40000 in general.

For playing in 1280 x 1024, even stretched to wide-screen, I can't say I noticed any truly painful spots. In a world of 8-bit indies, it's downright gorgeous.

Appearances to the side, the gameplay grabbed me right up - and more than just the gameplay, the atmosphere! Listening to the Space Marines call to one another, shouting their battle-cries to the accompaniment of a moving and powerful musical score... well, it's easy to remember why it was so brilliant back in the day.

THQ, the original publisher, is long gone. SEGA appears to hold the game now. Either way, Relic has been incredibly aware and active in the Steam forums, replacing Gamespy, repairing patches that damaged mods, and listening to the community in general. Relic won my heart with the original Homeworld game, and I'm glad to see that they're still a positive force in gaming.

If you're looking for a good RTS, a blast from a great past, or even just some Warhammer 40K, it would be hard to go wrong with Dawn of War. You can even paint your units...

The main story maybe isn't the longer in strategy games (just 11 missions) but the harder difficulty level you play on, the more fun it is. There are much more skirmish maps, where you can play with much more players/ai and have even more fun. Not just as Space Marines, but also as Orks or Chaos Space Marines. Dawn Of War is one of the best RTS games I've ever seen and is definitely worth the purchase and all of it's dlcs, at the time of writing they were all on sale for a combined price lower than 10 dollars, that is an absolute steal. In short, Dawn Of War is an RTS that contains:

- 9 Incredibly unique factions ranging from the undead/robotic necron, who do not require requisitions but need to build massive amounts of power to sustain themselves to the legendary Warhammer Space Marines, the super soldiers who define the series with their powerful leadership units and decent unit composition making impossible fights slightly more possible (Though the expansions are needed for 5 of them, by default you get Orks, Chaos Marines, Space Marines, and Eldar though they are pretty unique and can in themselves offer hundreds of hours of gameplay).

-Interesting game modes such as the standard destroy the enemy's base ranging to hold various points for a set amount of time or even just slay the enemy commander before yours falls. Plus, you can set more than one victory parameter for maximum gameplay and strategic influence.

-Expansions that change the singleplayer experience (Soulstorm and Dark Crusade) to a map takeover in which all of the game's factions wage war and fight numerous matches attacking and defending territory with troops they earned throughout the campaign and even their fation specific commander his/herself.

In the end, it is an amazing game well worth your time, though I do suggest getting the expansions as they make the already great game even better.

Pros:
+ Solid storyline
+ Bug-free
+ Classic RTS Gameplay
+ Clever use of flags
+ This is our land now
+ But do you have a flag?
+ Great Multiplayer/matchmaking

Cons:
- Game is a bit short; single-player campaign lasts roughly 20 hours
- Only four playable races; later expansions add more

Overall: Warhammer 40k is a fantastic board game franchise, but it's very expensive.  This is a solid introduction to the world in a fun, entertaining package.  If you played this game in its heyday, you really don't need me to tell you it's great.  If you're new, then know that this game stands the test of time, and is still fun so many years later.  It nails the RTS genre, and still looks good.  It plays smoothly, and rewards clever gameplay and tactics.  The later expansions give more campaigns and more opportunities for multiplayer shenanigans, but this game started it all.

Bottom Line: Worth playing and replaying, for old and new fans.  Familiarity with the Warhammer universe not required.

Ever wonder where Blizzard got most of their ideas for the Warcraft and Starcraft games? Look no further than Warhammer. This long-running series started out in the '80s as a tabletop strategy game, and transitioned to computer games not long after. The Dawn of War series takes place in the Warhammer 40,000 universe, and will have a very familiar feel to anyone who has played Blizzard's popular RTS games. No doubt you're already familiar with Space Marines and Orks. You'll find plenty of them here. Starcraft's Protoss and Zerg drew their inspiration from Warhammer's Eldar and Tyranid races, respectively. You'll also find several other factions unique to Warhammer, including the corrupt Chaos Marines, the undead robotic Necron, and the alien Tau. Even though the Dawn of War series was originally released in 2004, it still stands the test of time, and the many expansion packs keep things fresh and interesting. If you're a fan of any sci-fi RTS games, you'll love Dawn of War.

Warhammer 40,000: Dawn of War (Relic Entertainment) who also make Company of Heroes, The game is not the average strategy game you must hold certain points in the game to gain requistion points and build resources  and units while fighting off the enemies. There are many races in the game including the Chaos Space Marines, Space Marines, Eldar, and the Orks fight in ever-raging battle of the Planet Tartarus.

After a couple of years I reinstalled the game via Steam. And still I find it very good even though the graphics cannot compete with todays standard. But the multiplayer is always good for intense battles. This game is not over complex it gives you easy access but at the same time it gets deep when it comes to upgrades and all the different units and peoples. Capture the flag to get resources makes the game dynamic. It definitely is a golden oldie and recommended for everyone who likes to play a strategic game. And the setting of the Warhammer universe is just great.

Pros:
+ Solid storyline
+ Bug-free
+ Classic RTS Gameplay
+ Clever use of flags
+ This is our land now
+ But do you have a flag?
+ Great Multiplayer/matchmaking

Cons:
- Game is a bit short; single-player campaign lasts roughly 20 hours
- Only four playable races; later expansions add more

Overall: Warhammer 40k is a fantastic board game franchise, but it's very expensive.  This is a solid introduction to the world in a fun, entertaining package.  If you played this game in its heyday, you really don't need me to tell you it's great.  If you're new, then know that this game stands the test of time, and is still fun so many years later.  It nails the RTS genre, and still looks good.  It plays smoothly, and rewards clever gameplay and tactics.  The later expansions give more campaigns and more opportunities for multiplayer shenanigans, but this game started it all.

Bottom Line: Worth playing and replaying, for old and new fans.  Familiarity with the Warhammer universe not required.
